'''Hay'at Tahrir al-Sham''' ({{Lang-ar|هيئة تحرير الشام}}, [[Romanization of Arabic|transliteration]]: ''{{transl|ar|ALA|Hayʼat Taḥrīr al-Shām}}'',{{cite news |last= |first= |author=BBC Monitoring|date=12 February 2017 |title=Tahrir al-Sham: Al-Qaeda's latest incarnation in Syria |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-38934206 |newspaper=BBC News |location= |accessdate=}} "'''Organization for the Liberation of the Levant'''" or "'''Levant Liberation Committee'''"), commonly referred to as '''Tahrir al-Sham''' and abbreviated '''HTS''', also known as '''al-Qaeda'''{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/syria-opposition-trump-isis_us_58b9eb17e4b05cf0f400b612|title=Syria Rebels Want Trump To Know They're The Ones Fighting ISIS|author=Akbar Shahid Ahmed|work=huffingtonpost|date=3 March 2017|quote=Al Reis conceded that many anti-Assad Syrians in the north had become close to the Al Qaeda group, now known as Tahrir al-Sham.}}{{cite web|title=Tahrir al-Sham: Al-Qaeda's latest incarnation in Syria|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-38934206|work=BBC|date=28 February 2017|access-date=10 April 2018|quote=It appeared to be an attempt to further distance the group from al-Qaeda. But it is not clear how effective that will be, as the last name change failed to convince the international community and the US kept the group on its list of foreign terrorist organisations.}} '''in Syria''', is an active [[Salafist jihadist]] militant group involved in the [[Syrian Civil War]]. The group was formed on 28 January 2017 as a merger between [[al-Nusra Front|Jabhat Fateh al-Sham]] (formerly al-Nusra Front), the [[Ansar al-Din Front]], [[Jaysh al-Sunna]], [[Liwa al-Haqq (Idlib)|Liwa al-Haqq,]] and the [[Nour al-Din al-Zenki Movement]]. After the announcement, additional groups and individuals joined. The merged group is currently led by Jabhat Fatah al-Sham and former Ahrar al-Sham leaders, although the High Command consists of leaders from other groups.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-rebels-idUSKBN15C0MV|title=Syria Islamist factions, including former al Qaeda branch, join forces: statement|date=28 January 2017|accessdate=28 January 2017|agency=[[Reuters]]}} Many groups and individuals defected from [[Ahrar al-Sham]], representing their more conservative and Salafist elements. Currently, a number of analysts and media outlets still continue to refer to this group by its previous names, '''al-Nusra Front''', or '''Jabhat Fateh al-Sham'''.{{cite web|url=http://www.i24news.tv/en/news/international/middle-east/138571-170225-twin-suicide-attacks-on-bases-in-syria-s-homs-kill-35|title=Ex-Qaida affiliate Jabhat Fateh al-Sham claims Homs attacks which killed dozens|first=|last=i24NEWS|publisher=}} The Ansar al-Din Front{{cite web|url=http://nedaa-sy.com/en/news/4175|title=New component split from "Hay'at Tahrir al-Sham"|work=Syria Call|date=9 February 2018}} and Nour al-Din al-Zenki Movement have since split off from Tahrir al-Sham. Despite the merger, Tahrir al-Sham has been accused of working as [[al-Qaeda]]'s Syrian branch on a covert level, and that many of the group's senior figures, particularly Abu Jaber, held similarly extreme views.{{cite web |url= http://stopterrorfinance.org/stories/511082466-al-qaeda-s-grand-plan-for-syria-passes-through-hayat-tahrir-al-sham |title=Al-Qaeda's Grand Plan for Syria Passes Through Hayat Tahrir al-Sham |first=CATF|last=Reports|publisher=}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-38934206|title=Tahrir al-Sham: Al-Qaeda's latest incarnation in Syria|publisher=BBC News}} However, Tahrir al-Sham has officially denied being part of al-Qaeda and said in a statement that the group is "an independent entity and not an extension of previous organizations or factions". Additionally, some factions such as Nour al-Din al-Zenki, which was part of the merger, were once supported by the US.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/terror-list-omission-1.4114621 |title=Why Syria's al-Qaeda affiliate is no longer on Canada's terror list|publisher=}} Russia claims that Tahrir al-Sham shares al-Nusra Front's goal of turning Syria into an Islamic emirate run by al-Qaeda.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/russia-finds-new-jihadist-coalition-syria-worrisome-foreign-ministry/|title=Russia finds new jihadist coalition in Syria 'worrisome': Foreign Ministry |first=News|last=Desk|date=22 February 2017|publisher=[[Al-Masdar News]]}} ==History== ===Formation=== [[Abdullah al-Muhaysini]], Abu Taher al-Hamawi, and [[Abdelrazzak Mehdi|Abd ar-Razzaq al-Mahdi]] worked on the formation of the group.{{cite tweet|number=825807698423906304|user=ajaltamimi|title=#Syria: One might understand the...|accessdate=28 February 2017|date= 29 January 2017 }} On 28 January 2017, the date of their formation that Tahrir al-Sham was formed, the group announced the formation of its elite units, the "Inghimasi", some of whom were deployed in [[Idlib]] city. They could also be used for suicide infiltration operations and as assault troops.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/video-jihadist-coalition-forms-elite-unit-combat-syrian-army/|title=VIDEO: Jihadist coalition forms elite unit to combat the Syrian Army|first=Chris|last=Tomson|date=14 March 2017|publisher=[[Al-Masdar News]]}}{{Better source|date=September 2017}} ===Consolidation of power (2017)=== [[File:Hayat Tahrir al-Sham fighters in Mushairfa, northeastern Hama.png|250px|left|thumb|Fighters of Tahrir al-Sham in the village of Mushairfa, northeast of [[Hama]], during the [[Northeastern Hama offensive (2017)|northeastern Hama offensive]] in October 2017.]] On 30 January, there were reports of mobilizations by Tahrir al-Sham and [[Ahrar al-Sham]] at the [[Bab al-Hawa Border Crossing]] and other nearby areas, and that the two groups were preparing for another round of clashes.{{cn|date=November 2018}} On 30 January, it was reported that there were around 31,000 fighters in Tahrir al-Sham, while in March analyst Charles Lister described is as "likely commanding 12,000 to 14,000 fighters".Charles Lister, [https://foreignpolicy.com/2017/03/15/al-qaeda-is-swallowing-the-syrian-opposition/ Al Qaeda Is Starting to Swallow the Syrian Opposition], ''Foreign Policy'', 15 March 2017 Soon after the group's formation, many local Syrians began referring to the group as '''Hetesh''', which was an Arabic acronym meant as a pejorative, similar the "Daesh" label applied to ISIL by much of the Arab World. This labeling indicated that many Syrians saw Tahrir al-Sham as no different than ISIL, especially given the similarities between Tahrir al-Sham's recent attacks and ISIL's massive offensive on rebel forces in 2014.{{cite web |url= http://henryjacksonsociety.org/2017/02/06/analysis-al-qaeda-reshapes-the-insurgency-in-northern-syria/ |title= Analysis: 'Al-Qaeda Reshapes the Insurgency in Northern Syria' |date= 6 February 2017 |author= Kyle Orton |publisher= [[Henry Jackson Society]] |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170210104907/http://henryjacksonsociety.org/2017/02/06/analysis-al-qaeda-reshapes-the-insurgency-in-northern-syria/ |archivedate= 10 February 2017 |df= dmy-all }} HTS suffered losses from air attacks by Coalition forces. On 1 February 2017, pro-government media reported that the US had conducted an airstrike on Carlton Hotel, in the city of Idlib, which was used by Tahrir al-Sham's former al-Nusra component for troop housing, and hosting meetings of prominent commanders,{{cite web |url= https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/us-led-coalition-airstrike-targets-carlton-hotel-idlib-city/ |title= US-led Coalition airstrike targets Carlton Hotel in Idlib city |first=Andrew |last= Illingworth |date= 1 February 2017 |publisher= [[Al-Masdar News]]}}{{Better source|date=September 2017}} although opposition sources said the hotel was used by the [[Syrian Arab Red Crescent]][https://syriadirect.org/news/syrian-arab-red-crescent-center-in-idlib-city-badly-damaged-in-airstrike/ Syrian Arab Red Crescent center in Idlib city badly damaged in unclaimed airstrike], ''SyriaDirect'' 1 February 2017, and US involvement has not been confirmed.[https://www.bellingcat.com/news/mena/2017/02/09/asssessing-the-claim-that-the-us-bombed-an-aid-hq-in-syria/ Assessing the Claim that the United States Bombed an Aid Headquarters in Syria], ''Bellingcat'' February 9, 2017 By Christiaan Triebert On the same day, the Elite Division of the FSA was attacked by Tahrir al-Sham.{{cite tweet|number=827284919546109953|user=badly_xeroxed|title=Urgent: Tahrir al-Sham attack #FSA Al...|accessdate=28 February 2017|date= 2 February 2017 }}{{Better source|date=September 2017}} On 3 February, a US airstrike struck a Tahrir al-Sham headquarters in [[Sarmin]], killing 12 members of HTS and [[Jund al-Aqsa]]. 10 of the killed militants were HTS members.{{cite web |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-airstrikes-idUSKBN15I1YY |title= Air strikes kill 12 fighters in Syria's Idlib: monitor |work=Reuters |date=3 February 2017}} The airstrike also killed militant commander Ibrahim al-Rihaal Abu Bakr. There has been resistance to HTS by civilians in rebel areas it controls. On 3 February, hundreds of Syrians demonstrated under the slogan "There is no place for [[al-Qaeda]] in Syria" in the towns of [[Atarib]], [[Azaz]], [[Maarat al-Nu'man]] to protest against HTS. In response, supporters of HTS organized [[counter-protest]]s in [[al-Dana, Syria|al-Dana]], Idlib, Atarib, and [[Khan Shaykhun]].{{cite web |url= http://arabi21.com/story/982670/%D8%B3%D9%88%D8%B1%D9%8A%D9%88%D9%86-%D9%8A%D8%AA%D8%B8%D8%A7%D9%87%D8%B1%D9%88%D9%86-%D8%A8%D8%AC%D9%85%D8%B9%D8%A9-%D9%84%D8%A7-%D9%85%D9%83%D8%A7%D9%86-%D9%84%D9%84%D9%82%D8%A7%D8%B9%D8%AF%D8%A9-%D9%81%D9%8A-%D8%B3%D9%88%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A7-%D8%B4%D8%A7%D9%87%D8%AF|title=Syrians demonstrating collecting "no place for a base in Syria"|work=Arabi 21|date=3 February 2017}} In Idlib pro- Hayyat Tahrir al-Sham protests were held waving pictures of its leader [[Abu Jaber]] on 3 February 2017.{{cite news |last= |first= |date=3 February 2017 |title=سوريون ينتقدون رفع صور "هاشم الشيخ" في مظاهرات إدلب |url=https://www.enabbaladi.net/archives/128990 |newspaper=عنب بلدي أونلاين |location= |accessdate=}} Attendance at a speech by HTS cleric [[Abdullah al-Muhaysini]] was manipulated by drawing [[internally displaced person]]s and impoverished people with promises of [[motorcycle]]s and [[refrigerator]]s through a raffle.{{cite tweet|number=828648275024683008|user=Charles_Lister|title=#JFS/#HTS also came under criticism...|accessdate=28 February 2017|date=6 February 2017 }}{{Better source|date=February 2017}} On 4 February 2017, a US airstrike killed al-Qaeda commander [[Abu Hani al-Masri]], who was a part of Ahrar al-Sham at the time of his death. It was reported that he was about to defect to Tahrir al-Sham before his death.{{cite web|url=http://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2017/02/pentagon-11-al-qaeda-terrorists-killed-in-airstrikes-near-idlib-syria.php|title=Pentagon: 11 al Qaeda terrorists killed in airstrikes near Idlib, Syria - FDD's Long War Journal|publisher=}} On the same day, Tahrir al-Sham official Muslah al-Alyani criticized other groups for not joining Tahrir al-Sham, arguing that any group that "fought for Islam" would be bombed, regardless of terrorist designations. In his statement, he indicated that one of the reasons why most Ahrar al-Sham fighters refused to join Tahrir al-Sham was because the latter group contained terrorist-designated individuals.{{cite web|url=https://kyleorton1991.wordpress.com/2017/01/20/the-coalition-strikes-down-al-qaedas-leaders-in-syria/|title=The Coalition Strikes Down Al-Qaeda's Leaders In Syria|first=Kyle|last=Orton|date=20 January 2017|publisher=Kyle Orton}} Around 8 February, [[Abu Muhammad al-Maqdisi]] confirmed that 2 senior Jabhat Fateh al-Sham leaders, including former al-Nusra deputy leader [[Sami al-Oraydi]], left Tahrir al-Sham after its formation. A speech was released by Abu Jaber on 9 February.{{cite web |url=http://jihadology.net/2017/02/09/new-video-mesaage-from-hayyat-ta%e1%b8%a5rir-al-shams-hisham-al-shaykh-first-words/ |title=New video mesaage from Hayy'at Taḥrīr al-Shām's Hishām al-Shaykh: "First Words"|last= |first= |date=9 February 2017 |website=Jihadology |publisher= |accessdate= |quote=}} He emphasized his group being an "independent entity" and praised his "brothers" in the "Syrian [[Jihad]]". The statement included [[Anti-Shi'ism|derogatory rhetoric on Shia Muslims]].{{cite web|url= http://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2017/02/hayat-tahrir-al-sham-leader-calls-for-unity-in-syrian-insurgency.php|title=Hay'at Tahrir al Sham leader calls for 'unity' in Syrian insurgency|work=Long War Journal|author=THOMAS JOSCELYN|date=10 February 2017}} On 12 February, the Bunyan al-Marsous Operations Room, of which Tahrir al-Sham was a member, launched an [[Daraa offensive (February 2017)|offensive]] against the [[Syrian Army]] in [[Daraa]]'s Manshiyah district. Tahrir al-Sham forces reportedly began the attack with 2 [[suicide bomber]]s and [[car bomb]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.syriahr.com/en/?p=60794|title=At least 23 were killed today during an attack by the factions and Fateh al-Sham Front in Daraa al-Balad at the city of Daraa|work=[[Syrian Observatory for Human Rights]]|date=12 February 2017}} On 13 February, clashes erupted between the previously-allied Tahrir al-Sham and [[Jund al-Aqsa]], also called Liwa al-Aqsa, in northern Hama and southern Idlib.{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/world/2017/02/13/jihadist-rebel-groups-clash-in-northwest-syria--monitor/|title=Jihadist rebel groups clash in northwest Syria - monitor|work=Reuters|date=13 February 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://jihadology.net/2017/02/13/new-statement-from-hayyat-ta%e1%b8%a5rir-al-sham-excuses-and-warning-for-the-liwa-al-aqsa-group/ |title=New statement from Hayy'at Taḥrīr al-Shām: "Excuses and Warning for the Liwā' al-Āqsā Group"|last= |first= |date=13 February 2017 |website=Jihadology |publisher= |accessdate= |quote=}} On 15 February, Ahrar al-Sham published an infographic on its recent defections, claiming that only 955 fighters had defected to Tahrir al-Sham. There were also reports that Ahrar al-Sham, the [[Sham Legion]], [[Jaysh al-Izza]], the [[Turkistan Islamic Party in Syria]], and the Tamkin Brigade would soon merge to form a new organization called the [[Syrian Liberation Front]].{{cite web|url=http://en.abna24.com/news/middle-east/jund-al-aqsa-executes-hundred-members-of-rival-groups-in-idlib.html|title=Jund al-Aqsa executes hundred members of rival groups in Idlib|first=|last=FNA|date=15 February 2017|publisher=[[AhlulBayt News Agency (ABNA)]]}}{{cite web|url=http://en.farsnews.com/newstext.aspx?nn=13951205000681|title=Tens of Terrorists Killed, Wounded in Intensified Clashes amongst Rival Groups in Northern Syria|publisher=[[Farsnews]]}} On 19 February, HTS arrested local FSA commander Anas Ibrahim in [[Atarib]], and, in response, an anti-HTS protest was held in the town.{{cite AV media |people= |date=19 February 2017 |title=Popular demonstrations against for Hayat Tahrir al-Sham in the city of Aleppo Atarib Brive |trans-title= |medium= |language= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=45FKwFAoDBc |publisher=Qasioun News Agency |accessdate=28 February 2017}}[https://en.zamanalwsl.net/news/23587.html Assailants kidnap FSA commander near Atareb, Aleppo], zamanalwsl.net, 21 February 2017{{better source|date=September 2017}} On 20 February, a Ma'arat al-Numan Shura Council was created by the [[Sham Legion]], Ahrar al-Sham, and Tahrir al-Sham.{{cite tweet|number=833735053318451200|user=siteintelgroup|title=Tahrir al-Sham, Ahrar al-Sham, Faylaq...|date=20 Feb 2017 }}{{better source|date=September 2017}} On 22 February, Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova stated that Russia feared that Tahrir al-Sham would declare a new Islamic Emirate in northwestern Syria within a month, patterned after ISIL's self-styled "Caliphate" in Ar-Raqqah. On the same day, the [[Combating Terrorism Center]] reported that Jabhat Fateh al-Sham had formed the Tahrir al-Sham group due to its fear of being isolated, and to counter Ahrar al-Sham's recent expansion during the clashes in the Idlib Province.{{cite web|url=https://www.ctc.usma.edu/posts/the-formation-of-hayat-tahrir-al-sham-and-wider-tensions-in-the-syrian-insurgency|title=The Formation of Hay'at Tahrir al-Sham and Wider Tensions in the Syrian Insurgency|publisher=Combating Terrorism Center at West Point}} On 22 February, the last of Liwa al-Asqa's 2,100 militants left their final positions in [[Khan Shaykhun]], with unconfirmed reports in pro-government media that they were to join ISIL in the Ar-Raqqah Province after a negotiated withdrawal deal with Tahrir al-Sham and the Turkistan Islamic Party.{{cite web|url=http://syriadirect.org/news/search-for-the-dead-begins-in-idlib-after-islamic-state-linked-brigade-leaves-for-raqqa/|title=Search for the dead begins in Idlib after Islamic State-linked brigade leaves for Raqqa|publisher=SyriaDirect}} Afterward, Tahrir al-Sham declared terminating Liwa al-Aqsa, and promised to watch for any remaining cells.{{cite web|url=https://news.siteintelgroup.com/Jihadist-News/tahrir-al-sham-declare-terminating-liwa-al-aqsa.html|title=Tahrir al-Sham Declare Terminating Liwa al-Aqsa|first=|last=SITE|publisher=siteintelgroup.com}} On 26 February, a US airstrike in Al-Mastoumeh, Idlib Province, killed [[Abu Khayr al-Masri]], who was the deputy leader of al-Qaeda.{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/war-terror-who-abu-khayr-al-masri-al-qaeda-second-command-killed-drone-strike-syria-2497897|title=War On Terror: Who Is Abu Khayr al-Masri? Al Qaeda Second In Command Killed In Drone Strike In Syria|date=26 February 2017|publisher=IB Times}}{{cite web|url=https://www.stratfor.com/situation-report/syria-al-qaeda-deputy-killed-apparent-drone-strike|title=Syria: Al Qaeda Deputy Killed In Apparent Drone Strike|publisher=Stratfor}} The airstrike also killed another Tahrir al-Sham militant.{{cite web|url=http://orient-news.net/en/news_show/132758/0/Tahrir-al-Sham-fighters-killed-by-US-led-coalition-drone-near-Idlib|title=2 Tahrir al-Sham fighters killed by US-led coalition drone near Idlib|publisher=Orient News}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/02/27/middleeast/deputy-al-qaeda-leader-killed/index.html|title=Deputy al Qaeda leader killed In Syria|author=Hamdi Alkhshali and Barbara Starr|publisher=CNN}} In early March 2017, local residents in the Idlib Province who supported FSA factions accused Tahrir al-Sham of doing more harm than good, saying that all they've done is "kidnap people, set up checkpoints, and terrorize residents."{{cite web|url=http://syriadirect.org/news/residents-rally-against-hardline-islamists-%E2%80%98we%E2%80%99re-not-afraid-because-we%E2%80%99ve-got-nothing-to-lose%E2%80%99/#.WLclOfnwtik.twitter|title=Residents rally against hardline Islamists: 'We're not afraid because we've got nothing to lose'|publisher=SyriaDirect}} On 16 March, a [[2017 al-Jinah airstrike|US airstrike]] struck an al-Qaeda meeting in the village of al-Jinah, just southwest of [[Atarib]], killing at least 29 and possibly over 50 civilians; the US claimed the people targeted in the strike were "al-Qaeda militants" but the [[Syrian Observatory for Human Rights]] (SOHR), local residents and local officials have said that the building struck was a mosque filled with worshipers.{{cite news|last1=Hennigan|first1=W. J.|title=U.S. military denies airstrike hit mosque in Syria, following reports of dozens killed|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/middleeast/la-fg-syria-strike-20170317-story.html|accessdate=26 March 2017|work=Los Angeles Times|date=17 March 2017}}{{cite news |title=US insists Al Jinah raid targeted al-Qaeda, not mosque |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date=17 March 2017 |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/03/syria-mosque-attack-170318010309757.html}}{{cite web|last1=Triebert|first1=Christiaan|title=CONFIRMED: US Responsible for Aleppo Mosque Bombing - bellingcat|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/news/mena/2017/03/16/us-missile-remains-reportedly-recovered-from-site-of-aleppo-mosque-bombing/|website=bellingcat|accessdate=18 March 2017|date=16 March 2017}} On the morning of 21 March (local time), according to local activists, a US drone strike in Darkoush, Idlib Province, killed Abu Islam al-Masri, a high-ranking HTS commander. HTS commander Abu al-'Abbas al-Darir was also killed in the drone strike.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/us-coalition-kills-high-ranking-jihadist-commander-idlib/|title=US Coalition kills high ranking jihadist commander in Idlib|first=Leith|last=Fadel|date=21 March 2017|publisher=[[Al-Masdar News]]}} On the same day, Tahrir al-Sham launched the [[2017 Hama offensive]] against Syrian Government forces.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} On 24 March, two [[flatbed truck]]s carrying [[flour]] and belonging to an [[IHH (Turkish NGO)|IHH]]-affiliated Turkish relief organization were stopped at a HTS checkpoint at the entrance to [[Sarmada]]. HTS then seized the trucks and the flour, which was intended for a [[bakery]] in [[Saraqib]]. The seizure caused 2,000 families in the area to be cut off from a free supply of [[bread]].{{cite web|url=http://syriadirect.org/news/nusra-led-coalition-confiscates-flour-at-checkpoint-%E2%80%98we-won%E2%80%99t-give-it-up%E2%80%99/|title=Former Al-Qaeda affiliate confiscates flour at checkpoint: 'We won't give it up'|work=Syria:direct|date=27 March 2017}} In April 2017, [[Jaysh al-Islam]] attacked the HTS and expelled it from the territories under its control in Eastern Ghouta. On 3 May, HTS arrested [[Suhail Muhammad Hamoud]], "Abu [[BGM-71 TOW|TOW]]", a former FSA fighter, in a house raid in Idlib. Earlier, al-Hamoud had published a photograph of him [[smoking]] in front of a HTS billboard that [[Tobacco fatwa|prohibited smoking]].{{Cite web|url=http://aletihadpress.com/2017/05/04/%D9%84%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B0%D8%A7-%D8%A7%D8%B9%D8%AA%D9%82%D9%84%D8%AA-%D8%AC%D8%A8%D9%87%D8%A9-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%86%D8%B5%D8%B1%D8%A9-%D8%B3%D9%87%D9%8A%D9%84-%D8%A3%D8%A8%D9%88-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AA%D8%A7/|title=Why arrested victory Front "Suhail Abu tau"|work=Al-Etihad Press|date=4 May 2017}} On 20 May, the main faction of the Abu Amara Battalions joined Tahrir al-Sham, which "now boasts a fighting force of some 50,000 militants" according to one source.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/islamist-rebel-group-joins-al-qaeda-franchise-syria/|title=Islamist rebel group joins Al-Qaeda franchise in Syria|first=Chris|last=Tomson|accessdate=21 May 2017|publisher=[[Al-Masdar News]]|date=21 May 2017}} However, the [[covert operation]]s unit of the Abu Amara Battalions based in Aleppo remained independent.{{cite web|url=http://www.all4syria.info/Archive/412366|title=باستثناء قائدها جفالة… كتائب (أبو عمارة) تعلن انضمامها لـ (تحرير الشام)|publisher=All4Syria}} On 27 May, Tahrir al-Sham and [[Saraya Ahl al-Sham]] clashed with the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] in the western [[Qalamoun Mountains]] near [[Arsal]], [[Lebanon–Syria border]]. 33 fighters were killed from both sides. On 29 May, Tahrir al-Sham arrested opposition activist and FSA commander [[Abdul Baset al-Sarout]] after accusing him of participating in an anti-HTS protest in [[Maarat al-Nu'man]].{{Cite web|url=http://aletihadpress.com/2017/05/30/%D8%AC%D8%A8%D9%87%D8%A9-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%86%D8%B5%D8%B1%D8%A9-%D8%AA%D8%B9%D8%AA%D9%82%D9%84-%D8%B9%D8%A8%D8%AF-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A8%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%B7-%D8%B3%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%AA-%D8%A8%D8%AA%D9%87/|title=Front victory arrest Abdul Baset Al-Sarout on charges of incitement|work=Al Etihad Press|date=30 May 2017}} On 2 June 2017, defectors from the Northern Brigade's Commandos of Islam Brigade reportedly joined Tahrir al-Sham, although Captain Kuja, leader of the unit, stated that he is still part of the Northern Brigade.{{Cite web|url=http://www.alnour.com.lb/ar/news/security/2017-06-02_132729/%D9%83%D8%AA%D9%8A%D8%A8%D8%A9-%D8%AA%D9%82%D8%A7%D8%AF-%D9%88%D9%83%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A6%D8%A8-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A5%D8%B3%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%85-%D9%8A%D9%86%D9%81%D9%8A%D8%A7%D9%86-%D9%85%D8%A8%D8%A7%D9%8A%D8%B9%D8%AA%D9%87%D9%85%D8%A7-%D9%84%D9%80%D9%87%D9%8A%D8%A6%D8%A9-%D8%AA%D8%AD%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%B1-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B4%D8%A7|title="Battalion driven" and "Islam Brigades" deny Mbaiathma for "Sham edit body"|work=Al-Nour|date=2 June 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.all4syria.info/Archive/415034|title=Northern Brigade separates from Sham Legion|work=All4Syria|date=30 May 2017}} On 20 July 2017, the Nour al-Din al-Zenki Movement led by Sheikh Tawfiq Shahabuddin announced its withdrawal from Tahrir al-Sham amid [[Idlib Governorate clashes (July 2017)|widespread conflict]] between HTS and Ahrar al-Sham, and became an independent Islamist group. On 23 July 2017, Tahrir al-Sham expelled the remnants of [[Ahrar al-Sham]] from Idlib, capturing the entire city{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-4722840/Jihadists-control-Syrias-Idlib-rebel-pull-monitor.html|title=Jihadists take control of major Syrian city|work=Mail Online|access-date=2017-07-23}} as well as 60% of the [[Idlib Governorate]].{{cite web|url=http://sn4hr.org/wp-content/pdf/english/Report_of_violations_of_the_Hay’et_Tahrir_al%20Sham_en.pdf|title=Hay'at Tahrir al Sham Commits Wide Violations in Idlib Governorate|work=[[Syrian Network for Human Rights]]|date=21 October 2017}} On 18 August 2017, Tahrir al-Sham captured 8 rebel fighters from the town of [[Madaya, Syria|Madaya]] after it accused them of wanting to return to Madaya during a [[Syrian Civil War ceasefires#Fifth ceasefire attempt (July–August 2017)|ceasefire agreement]].{{cite web|url=https://en.zamanalwsl.net/news/29129.html|title=Idlib: Tahrir al-Sham arrests 8 fighters fled Madaya town|work=Zaman al-Wasl|date=20 August 2017}} On 1 October 2017, the [[ibn Taymiyyah]] Battalions based in the town of [[Darat Izza]] defected from Tahrir al-Sham.{{cite web|url=http://qasioun.net/ar/news/show/100013/%D8%AA%D8%AD%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%B1_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B4%D8%A7%D9%85_%D8%AA%D8%A8%D9%8A%D9%86_%D9%85%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%A8%D8%B3%D8%A7%D8%AA_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A3%D8%AD%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%AB_%D9%81%D9%8A_%D9%85%D8%AF%D9%8A%D9%86%D8%A9_%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%A9_%D8%B9%D8%B2%D8%A9_%D8%BA%D8%B1%D8%A8_%D8%AD%D9%84%D8%A8|title=Edit the Sham show the events of events in the city of Dara Azza West of Aleppo|work=Qasioun News Agency|date=2 October 2017}} In November 2017, violent clashes erupted between the Nour al-Din al-Zenki Movement and Tahrir al-Sham in northern Idlib and western Aleppo, mainly in the area between [[Atme]] and [[Khan al-Asal]]. ===Terrorist attacks=== On 25 February 2017, 5{{cite tweet|number=835392629672140800|user=MousaAlomar|title=عاجل | خمس انغماسيين لهيئة تحرير...|accessdate=28 February 2017|date=24 February 2017 }}

{{cite tweet|number=835726268553392128|user=mmmlmnmmlnl|title=لله در #هيئة_تحرير_الشام، عشرات...|accessdate=28 February 2017|date=25 February 2017 }}

{{cite tweet|number=835761549100843008|user=wkaltnbd|title=الذين أقضوا مضجع الأسد وقتلو50عنصر...|date= 26 Feb 2017 }} One of the attackers was a Khan Shaykhun native called Abu Hurayra (Safi Qatini), according to social media sources.{{cite tweet|number=836238709754310656|user=MousaAlomar|title=صافي قطيني ( ابو هريرة ) من خان شيخون...|accessdate=28 February 2017|date=27 February 2017 }} The State Security branch chief and Military security branch chief died in the attack, according to social media sources.{{cite tweet|number=835732484436406274|user=mmmlmnmmlnl|title=ماذا نسمي المعارض (الوطني الشريف...|accessdate=28 February 2017|date=25 February 2017 }} Hassan Daaboul was among the 40 assassinated by Hayyat Tahrir al-Sham.{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/opinion/comment/what-daabuls-death-says-about-jihadism-in-syria|title=What Daabul's death says about jihadism in Syria - The National|author=Hassan Hassan|work=The National|date=26 February 2017|publisher=}}

{{cite tweet|number=835711536991731712|user=LongWarJournal|title=Syrian military intelligence official...|accessdate=28 February 2017|date=25 February 2017 }} Syrian reporter [[Moussa al-Omar]] posted pictures of officers and soldiers who were killed.{{cite tweet|number=835529838769360898|user=MousaAlomar|title=النظام ينعي عشرات القتلى من جنوده...|accessdate=28 February 2017|date=25 February 2017 }} The War Center Media gave a figure of six suicide attackers and a death toll of thirty.{{cite tweet|number=835408973054554113|user=MousaAlomar|title=الاستشهادي تقبله الله ومن غلاوة رئيس...|accessdate=28 February 2017|date=25 February 2017 }} The death toll was given at twenty by Moussa when he posted it a breaking.{{cite tweet|number=835418994886774785|user=MousaAlomar|title=أول خبر كان قبل سبوتنيك وقبل تبني...|accessdate=28 February 2017|date=25 February 2017 }} The death toll was given at thirty five on 24 February according to Moussa.{{cite tweet|number=835396665334988800|user=MousaAlomar|title=عاجل | مقتل اللواء حسن دعبول رئيس فرع...|accessdate=28 February 2017|date=24 February 2017 }} The injured numbered fifty four and the dead numbered forty seven on 25 February according to Moussa.{{cite tweet|number=835427611199275008|user=MousaAlomar|title=عاجل | ارتفاع عدد قتلى عناصر وضباط...|accessdate=28 February 2017|date=25 February 2017 }} Abu Yusuf al-Muhajir, a Tahrir al-Sham military spokesman was interviewed by Human Voice on the bombings.{{cite news |last=مهنا |first=ناجي |date=26 February 2017 |title=بالأسماء: توثيق مقتل 31 ضباط في تفجير حمص |url=https://human-voice.co/policy/7214/ | work=هيومن فويس |location= |accessdate=}}

{{cite tweet|number=835811797512896512|user=mmmlmnmmlnl|title=أبو يوسف المهاجر -الناطق العسكري باسم...|accessdate=28 February 2017|date=26 February 2017 }} Twenty-six names were released.{{cite news |last=محمد |first=حسام |date=26 February 2017 |title=تفاصيل ومعلومات حصرية حول تفجيرات حمص |url=https://human-voice.co/policy/7221/ | work=هيومن فويس |location= |accessdate=}} Sheikh Samir bin Ali Ka'aka Abu Abdurrahman from Eastern Ghouta suggested that the attack was carried out by Iranians in a dispute between Russians and Iranians.{{cite tweet|number=835688658036539400|user=sameerkakeh|title=منقوووووووووووووووول ما حصل في حمص...|accessdate=28 February 2017|date= 25 February 2017 }}

The death toll included 43 Iraqi pilgrims.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/03/hardline-group-syria-claims-deadly-damascus-bombings-170312151904118.html|title=Tahrir al-Sham claims bombings in Syria's Damascus|publisher=}}
{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-39250040|title=Syrian Al-Qaeda affiliate claims twin bombing in Damascus|date=12 March 2017|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com}} The attacks were at a shrine frequented by Shi'ite pilgrims and militiamen.[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-damascus-idUSKBN16I0B2 At least 40 killed in Damascus bombing targeting Shi'ites] ''[[Reuters]]'' 11 March 2017 They were described in a statement attributed to Tahrir al-Sham as targeting Iran-backed militias and pro-Assad fighters.[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-damascus-idUSKBN16J0QM Syrian jihadists say responsible for Damascus double bomb attack] ''[[Reuters]] 12 March 2017 ===2018=== In early 2018, there were reports that HTS had been significantly weakened, and now had "a small presence in Eastern Ghouta and declining influence in Idlib, northern Hama, and western Aleppo provinces", with just 250 men in Eastern Ghouta{{cite web | last=Petkova | first=Mariya | title=Where is al-Qaeda in Syria? | website=Al Jazeera | date=1 March 2018 | url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/03/al-qaeda-syria-180301152110387.html | access-date=15 November 2018}} In February 2018, Tahrir al-Sham was accused of killing Fayez al-Madani, an opposition delegate tasked with negotiations with the government over [[electricity delivery]] in the northern [[Homs Governorate]], in the city of [[al-Rastan]]. Hundreds of people, including fighters of the Men of God Brigade, part of the [[Free Syrian Army]]'s National Liberation Movement group,{{cite web|url=https://docs.google.com/document/d/1aI3yAmNGW1vLpJCOrhiVLqpUUIX9PG1RNsCqJGGfhxI/edit|title=Syrian Civil War factions|publisher=}} proceeded to demonstrate against HTS in the city on 13 February. In response, HTS withdrew from Rastan and handed over its headquarters in the city to the Men of God Brigade.{{cite web|url=http://syriadirect.org/news/hts-leaves-north-homs-town-following-civilian-protests/|title=HTS leaves north Homs town following civilian protests|work=[[Syria Direct]]|date=14 February 2018}} A breakaway faction of former HTS members was formed in February 2018, called the [[Guardians of Religion Organization]].{{cite web|url=https://syrianwardaily.wordpress.com/2018/02/28/syrian-war-daily-28th-of-february-2018/|title=Syrian War Daily – 28th of February 2018|work=Syrian War Daily|date=28 February 2018|author=Joško Barić}}{{better source|[[WP:SPS]]|date=September 2018}} HTS was left excluded of the 24 February ceasefire agreement on Eastern Ghouta. In late February, a group of armed factions, including [[Failaq al-Rahman]] and [[Jaysh al-Islam]], wrote to the UN declaring they were ready to "evacuate" remaining HTS fighters from Eastern Ghouta within 15 days. At the same time in Idlib Governorate, Ahrar al-Sham, Nour al-Din al-Zinki and Soqour al-Sham entered into [[Syrian Liberation Front–Tahrir al-Sham conflict|conflict with HTS]], taking significant territory. ==Ideology and governance== Abu Jaber, one of Tahrir al-Sham's leaders, has [[Salafist jihadist]] beliefs. This has resulted in him being arrested several times by the [[Syrian government]]. He was imprisoned at the [[Sednaya Prison]] in 2005 and released among several jihadist prisoners in 2011 who would form several Salafist rebel groups during the Syrian Civil War. Abu Jaber has also professed a belief in "Popular Jihad", a bottom-to-top approach in which jihadists would win the hearts and minds of the people, before setting out to establish jihadi governance, after receiving enough popular support, which is notably the opposite of ISIL's "elite Jihad" top-to-bottom approach. Analysts have also argued that the group continues to maintain many of [[al-Nusra Front]]'s al-Qaeda ideologies. Syrian reporter [[Abdullah Suleiman Ali]] also said that many of the former Jabhat Fateh al-Sham fighters still answered to al-Qaeda, and held an increasing amount of sway over the new group, despite its public rebranding.{{cite web|url=https://www.strategic-culture.org/news/2017/02/21/will-major-opposition-groups-face-off-syria.html|title=Will major opposition groups face off in Syria?|author=Haytham Mouzahem|date=17 February 2017|publisher=Al-Monitor}} Tahrir al-Sham continues to harbor the former al-Nusra Front's goal of turning Syria into an Islamic Emirate, if such a governing entity were declared, it would be similar to ISIL's declaration of a Caliphate, according to Kremlin diplomats. The [[Combating Terrorism Center]] also reported that despite public statements by some of Tahrir al-Sham's top figures, the group was still largely the same al-Qaeda-aligned group it was, back when it was known as al-Nusra. Lebanese researcher [[Muhammad Alloush]] said that the goal of forming Tahrir al-Sham was to unite all groups with al-Qaeda's extreme ideology under one banner, and to obtain as many weapons as possible. In July, 2017, according to a pro-government blog, the organization published an infographic showing some of its objectives. Among them were; "rejection of secularism and democracy", "establishment of an Islamic state", "rule by the Islamic scholars based on the sharia law" and "rejection of political rapprochement with the criminal regime (i.e. Syrian government)".{{cite web|url=https://southfront.org/hayat-tahrir-al-sham-reveals-new-principles-objectives/|title=Hay'at Tahrir al-Sham Reveals Its "New" Principles And Objectives|date=13 July 2017|publisher=South Front blog}}{{better source|date=September 2017}} ===Public opinion=== The ECHO Research Centre at [[Laurentian University]] conducted an [[opinion poll]] on 4,858 residents in several areas of Syria between 10 July 2017 and 28 July 2017. According to the poll's results, 77% of those surveyed disagreed with the Salafist ideology Tahrir al-Sham and other Salafist groups promote in Idlib, 73% rejected HTS-affiliated local councils in Idlib, 66% agreed that HTS is part of al-Qaeda in Syria, and 63% claimed that the dominance of HTS in Idlib will lead to a "second [[Battle of Tora Bora|Tora Bora]]". Of those who participated in the poll, nearly all of them (close to 100%) considered HTS to be contrary to the goals of the [[Syrian opposition]], although they were split in its extent. 51% of them considered HTS to be contrary to the opposition since its inception, 42% considered HTS to be previously consistent with the opposition, but is no longer so, and 7% considered HTS to be a [[counter-revolutionary]] organization.{{cite web|url=http://www.all4syria.info/Archive/437312|title=A poll of the population of Idlib .. in light of the deportation of web|url=http://news.siteintelgroup.com/blog/index.php/categories/jihad/entry/434-has-al-qaeda-replanted-its-flag-in-syria-1|title=Has al-Qaeda Replanted its Flag in Syria?|publisher=}} ===Ahrar al-Sham=== According to [[Abdul Razzaq al-Mahdi]], who was a leading scholar in Tahrir al-Sham, the groups do not particularly hate one another in the political or social battlefield. Certain members, however, do believe that a war between the two would be possible, since Ahrar al-Sham's attendance at the Astana talks labels it as a "moderate" faction, often seen as blasphemy within groups such as Tahrir al-Sham.{{cite web|url=http://ogn.news/tashm/|title=Is Tahreer Sham gearing up for a fight with Ahrar?|first=OGN|last=News|date=2 February 2017|publisher=}} In February 2018 Ahrar al-Sham and the [[Nour al-Din al-Zenki Movement]] merged and formed the [[Syrian Liberation Front]] then launched an [[Idlib Governorate clashes (February 2018)|offensive]] against Tahrir al-Sham seizing several villages and the city of [[Maarrat al-Nu'man]]. ==Designation as a terrorist organization== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- |Country |Date |References |- |{{USA}} |11 March 2017 |https://twitter.com/Charles_Lister/status/840557108483485696{{cite tweet |user=USEmbassySyria |author=''[[United States Ambassador to Syria]]'' |number=864138586672828416 |date=15 May 2017 |title=HTS is a merger and any group that merges into it becomes part of al-Qa'ida's Syrian network. #Syria}} |- |{{CAN}} |23 May 2018 |http://gazette.gc.ca/rp-pr/p2/2018/2018-05-30/html/sor-dors103-eng.html |- |{{TUR}} |31 August 2018 |https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-mideast-crisis-syria-turkey/turkey-designates-syrias-tahrir-al-sham-as-terrorist-group-idUKKCN1LG1XU |} Most of the international community considers Tahrir al-Sham to be a terrorist organisation. The US embassy in Syria confirmed on May 2017 that HTS had been [[List of designated terrorist groups|designated a terrorist organization]] in March 2017.[https://www.alaraby.co.uk/english/news/2017/5/16/us-denies-reports-syria-rebels-nusra-off-terror-list US denies reports Syria rebels Nusra off terror list], Al-Araby, 16 May 2017 The [[United States Ambassador to Syria]] stated that "HTS is a merger and any group that merges into it becomes part of al-Qaeda's Syrian network."{{cite tweet |user=USEmbassySyria |author=''[[United States Ambassador to Syria]]'' |number=864138586672828416 |date=15 May 2017 |title=HTS is a merger and any group that merges into it becomes part of al-Qa'ida's Syrian network. #Syria}} and "the core of HTS is Nusra, a designated terrorist organization. This designation applies regardless of what name it uses or what groups merge into it."{{cite tweet |user=USEmbassySyria |author=''[[United States Ambassador to Syria]]'' |number=864137666102734849 |date=15 May 2017 |title=The core of HTS is Nusra, a designated terrorist org. This designation applies regardless of what name it uses or what groups merge into it.}} [[Canada]] designated Tahrir al-Sham as a terrorist organization on 23 May 2018.[http://gazette.gc.ca/rp-pr/p2/2018/2018-05-30/html/sor-dors103-eng.html Regulations Amending the Regulations Establishing a List of Entities: SOR/2018-103] In August 2018, [[Turkey]] designated Tahrir al-Sham as a terrorist organization.https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-turkey/turkey-designates-syrias-tahrir-al-sham-as-terrorist-group-idUSKCN1LG1XM ==Alleged foreign support== Iran's government has "accused [[Qatar]] and [[Saudi Arabia]] of supporting Tahrir al-Sham.""[http://en.farsnews.com/newstext.aspx?nn=13951121000712 Confrontation between Turkey, Saudi Arabia Root Cause of Tensions among Terrorist Groups in Syria]". [[Fantasy]] | publisher = | pub_date = 1999 | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = | isbn = 0590395912 | oclc = | dewey = | congress = }} {{Portal |Children's literature}} '''''The Ant Bully''''' ({{ISBN|0590395912}}) is a 1999 [[children's book]] drawn and written by [[John Nickle]]. It is about a young boy named Lucas Nickle (also known as Peanut the Destroyer), who is the [[title character]] in the book and who likes to torment [[ant]]s. It was later adapted into a [[The Ant Bully (film)|computer-animated film of the same name]] by [[John A. Davis]], produced by [[Legendary Pictures]] and [[DNA Productions]] for [[Warner Bros. Pictures]]. ==Story== Lucas is a boy who is perceived as "strange" by his peers due to his funny glasses and propeller beanie (hat). Sid, the neighborhood bully, continuously bullies Lucas by spraying him with a water hose and stealing his hat. In an attempt to cope with Sid's actions, Lucas projects his anger onto a local colony of ants by spraying them with water, just as Sid has done to him. The ants have enough and tackle and shove Lucas into the queen's chamber, and the queen confronts him about all of the trouble he has caused the colony. When Lucas is too shocked to even respond to her, the queen takes it as an insult, and orders an ant wizard to shrink the boy down to the size of an ant and take him to trial, where the judge declares him guilty. His punishment is to work hard like an ant, working in the field, gathering food, defending the colony from wasps and spiders, and taking care of the queen, the worst part of his punishment. After a while, the queen tells Lucas that he has one last test to be set free: he must go home and bring her a Red Sweet Rock (jelly bean). Lucas brings two ants with him on the journey, and they ask him what it's like being a giant. Lucas tells them that he isn't a giant and gets picked on by Sid, who does all the same things Lucas does to the ants. When they reach his house, they find a box of swell jells, but Lucas's father sees the ants and tries to smash them with a fly swatter. Lucas shouts at his dad to stop, helping the ants to escape. Meanwhile, the queen is upset, fearing that Lucas was killed, but to her surprise he returns, and as promised she gives him the potion to return him to his right size. Lucas falls asleep and wakes up to see Sid, only to his surprise the ants got to him first and shrunk him as revenge. ==External links== * ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20080505004852/http://johnnickle.net/html/antbully.html The Ant Bully]'' at JohnNickle.net *''[http://readingtokids.org/Books/BookView.php?bookID=00000686 ReadingtoKids.org ]'' {{DEFAULTSORT:Ant Bully, The}} [[Category:1999 children's books]] [[Category:American picture books]] [[Category:Children's fiction books]] [[Category:Books adapted into films]] [[Category:Fiction about insects]] {{child-picture-book-stub}} [[de:Lucas, der Ameisenschreck]]
